I'm not sure I can really add much that others haven't already said, but I'll throw my hat in. Yes, it's completely normal. I bet if you talked to your friends all of them would also be questioning something or other in the faith. Those who aren't either will in a few years or are lying out of insecurity.
I started questioning at about your age, and started trying to justify the Church's beliefs with my own reasoning which was, unbeknownst to me at the time, largely based on secular humanism with little actual theology to back it up. If I couldn't reconcile a part of the faith with my own system, I threw it out and figured the Church just hadn't caught up to the world yet.
For whatever reason, it never really occurred to me that a 2000 year old institution might have just thought these things through a time or two in the past. I was working under the false narrative given by the world that religious people were just operating on blind faith with no reasoning behind it, and you were better off figuring things out yourself and making your own morality. But you wouldn't try to invent your own math or physics from scratch - it's best to look at what's come before and see the solutions to problems that have already been discovered and worked out.
Once I did that, it all changed. I saw how much sense the Church's doctrines made when reasoned out, and how little foundation secular views had. They couldn't base their beliefs on anything objective, whereas the Church had God and His Word. Not to mention reason from Natural Law. That all made everything fall into place. I was a grad student in AI at a top Computer Science University, and when I started learning about the faith, I saw how reductionist all the assumptions were in the scientific community. You can still have science as a Catholic, but so many people want to make empirical evidence all that there is, when there's a far richer world we inhabit. Reducing it to simple particle and wave interactions takes away the beauty and meaning. You need to look at the world in a totally different light, which is very difficult for people born in an age where a materialist, empiricist outlook is basically assumed. Right now I'm a seminarian studying to be a priest, and I'm still fascinated by all the philosophy and theology I'm learning. It's really given me a much more complete outlook on the world.
TL;DR Questioning is healthy. Just make sure you're actually looking for answers instead of doubting for the sake of doubt. They're out there and easily accessible (though not always easy to understand).

Hello fellow CS masochist! I was originally going for my PhD as well, but I decided to get a Master's and get out of Dodge. Turns out I'm good at academia but hate research. Just couldn't get motivated for it. Maybe it was the lab I joined, maybe it was my disposition.But that's neither here nor there. My biggest recommendations are
1) Choose by professor/research topic, not how big-name the school is. Read research journals and also focus on conferences. CS is different from many other areas in that the conferences can be almost as big a deal as the journals.
2) Only keep going if it's something you know you love. If you would follow the field anyway, even if you had to do something else in your life - if you would read the material on your own and get excited about minor advances in obscure fields, you're probably a good fit. The best researchers are like that. I wasn't, and I had to force myself to do anything, and I realized it wasn't for me. I was one of the top performers in the classes at a top-level school (particularly in AI, which was my area), but it didn't mean squat for whether I should get the PhD. The best researcher I knew was a labmate of mine. The guy was a research machine. Published from his second year, and was on at least 4 or 5 papers every year after, usually as first or second author. He was always carrying around a different advanced math book every time I saw him on the off-chance some obscure area could apply to his research methods. Looking at him made me realize that it wasn't my calling, despite my smarts. Also I was coming back into full practice of the Catholic faith again, and was embracing the concept of vocation. I decided to go into teaching after and loved it (with some caveats), but still felt like I might be called to something else. Now I'm in seminary figuring out if that's what I need to be doing. So I guess keep an open mind along the way and figure out if a PhD is your calling. And keep in mind that nobody can make you stay on one path if you don't like it.
